leanCodeSectionsTree.body:
User notes:
About this chapter: Chapter 22 provides the minimum requirements for the design and construction of structural steel (including composite construction), cold-formed steel, steel joists, steel cable structures and steel storage racks. This chapter specifies appropriate design and construction standards for these types of structures. It also provides a road map of the applicable technical requirements for steel structures. Chapter 22 requires that the design and use of steel structures and components be in accordance with the applicable specifications and standards of the American Institute of Steel Construction, the American Iron and Steel Institute, the Steel Joist Institute and the American Society of Civil Engineers.
Code development reminder: Code change proposals to this chapter will be considered by the IBC—Structural Code Development Committee during the 2022 (Group B) Code Development Cycle.

diagrams.title: Beam Pocket
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Beam pockets might be used to allow the top of a concrete retaining or other wall to align with the top of a beam. If beam pockets interrupt a chord of concrete shear wall, special consideration should be made to ensure continuity of the chord around the pocket. In addition, if the wall the beam is set in is also a fire-resistive assembly, then the minimum concrete thickness on the back side of the beam should comply with Chapter 7 of the building code and attention to the protection of the end of the beam may be required as well.

diagrams.title: Steel Floor / Roof with Metal Deck: Example 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Composite steel and concrete deck construction has steel decking spanning between steel beams. These steel beams have welded studs that create an interface with the concrete. This causes the steel beam and the steel deck to structurally operate as a single system, similar to a T-beam concrete beam/slab system. The concrete may have embedded rebar for masonry parapets or embeds for things such as bracing or suspended ceiling systems. Coordination with the Structural Engineer of Record is necessary to ensure the proper assembly is selected to provide the proper fire ratings. In addition, Sprayed Fire-Resistant Materials may be required on the underside of the deck to provide the requisite resistance rating.

diagrams.title: Steel Floor / Roof with Metal Deck: Example
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Composite steel and concrete deck construction has steel decking spanning between steel beams. These steel beams have welded studs that create an interface with the concrete. This causes the steel beam and the steel deck to structurally operate as a single system, similar to a T-beam concrete beam/slab system. The concrete may have embedded rebar for masonry parapets or embeds for things such as bracing or suspended ceiling systems. Coordination with the Structural Engineer of Record is necessary to ensure the proper assembly is selected to provide the proper fire ratings. In addition, Sprayed Fire-Resistant Materials may be required on the underside of the deck to provide the requisite resistance rating.

diagrams.title: Elevator Sill Depression: Example
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Consideration should be given to forming of concrete at elevator entry locations, so an elevator sill level with the floor, can be installed.

children.body: The provisions of this chapter govern the quality, design, fabrication and erection of steel construction.

children.displayTitle: Section 2202 Identification of Steel for Structural Purposes
children.titleText: Identification of Steel for Structural Purposes

children.body: Identification of structural steel elements shall be in accordance with AISC 360. Identification of cold-formed steel members shall be in accordance with AISI S100. Identification of cold-formed steel light-frame construction shall also comply with the requirements contained in AISI S240 or AISI S220, as applicable. Other steel furnished for structural load-carrying purposes shall be properly identified for conformity to the ordered grade in accordance with the specified ASTM standard or other specification and the provisions of this chapter. Where the steel grade is not readily identifiable from marking and test records, the steel shall be tested to verify conformity to such standards.

children.displayTitle: Section 2203 Protection of Steel for Structural Purposes
children.titleText: Protection of Steel for Structural Purposes

children.body: Painting of structural steel elements shall be in accordance with AISC 360. Painting of open-web steel joists and joist girders shall be in accordance with SJI 100 and SJI 200. Individual structural members and assembled panels of cold-formed steel construction shall be protected against corrosion in accordance with the requirements contained in AISI S100. Protection of cold-formed steel light-frame construction shall be in accordance with AISI S240 or AISI S220, as applicable.

diagrams.title: Example: Tube Columns to Concrete Slab

children.body: The details of design, workmanship and technique for welding and qualification of welding personnel shall be in accordance with the specifications listed in Sections 2205, 2206, 2207, 2208, 2210 and 2211. For special inspection of welding, see Section 1705.2.

The design, installation and inspection of bolts shall be in accordance with the requirements of Sections 2205, 2206, 2207, 2210 and 2211. For special inspection of the installation of high-strength bolts, see Section 1705.2.

Anchor rods shall be set in accordance with the approved construction documents. The protrusion of the threaded ends through the connected material shall fully engage the threads of the nuts but shall not be greater than the length of the threads on the bolts.

diagrams.title: Individual vs. Membrane Protection of Steel Beams
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where the fire-resistance rating of structural members based on construction type is required by table 601, primary steel beams must be protected by individual encasement on all sides. Secondary members associated with floor and roof assemblies may be protected by individual encasement or membrane protection.

diagrams.title: Example: Metal Deck Openings, Details 1 & 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An example is shown of one method of reinforcing openings in metal decks. Appropriate details should be developed by the project's structural engineer of record on a case by case basis. Openings in the diaphragm affect the shear flow to the lateral force resisting system, and larger openings, or openings placed near the LFRS, requires even more attention.

diagrams.title: Example: Metal Deck Openings, Details 3 & 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An example is shown of one method of reinforcing openings in metal decks. Appropriate details should be developed by the project's structural engineer of record on a case by case basis. Openings in the diaphragm affect the shear flow to the lateral force resisting system, and larger openings, or openings placed near the LFRS, requires even more attention.

diagrams.title: Example: Steel Beam w/ Stiffeners at Column
Example: Folding Partition Support
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Items such as folding partitions not only need to be designed to suspend the dead load of the item, but also designed to consider factors such as lateral loads, the maximum allowed deflection of the track by the manufacturer (i.e. how much the supporting beam will deflect) and likely other requirements. Working closely with the structural engineer and the manufacturer's representative will help ensure a properly designed support.

children.body: The design, fabrication and erection of structural steel elements in buildings, structures and portions thereof shall be in accordance with AISC 360.
Where required, the seismic design, fabrication and erection of buildings, structures and portions thereof shall be in accordance with Section 2205.2.1 or 2205.2.2, as applicable.
The design, detailing, fabrication and erection of structural steel seismic force-resisting systems shall be in accordance with the provisions of Section 2205.2.1.1 or 2205.2.1.2, as applicable.

Structures assigned to Seismic Design Category B or C shall be of any construction permitted in Section 2205. Where a response modification coefficient, R, in accordance with ASCE 7, Table 12.2-1, is used for the design of structures assigned to Seismic Design Category B or C, the structures shall be designed and detailed in accordance with the requirements of AISC 341. Beam-to-column moment connections in special moment frames and intermediate moment frames shall be prequalified in accordance with AISC 341, Section K1, qualified by testing in accordance with AISC 341, Section K2, or shall be prequalified in accordance with AISC 358.
Exception: The response modification coefficient, R, designated for "Steel systems not specifically detailed for seismic resistance, excluding cantilever column systems" in ASCE 7, Table 12.2-1, shall be permitted for systems designed and detailed in accordance with AISC 360, and need not be designed and detailed in accordance with AISC 341.
children.displayTitle: 2205.2.1.1 Seismic Design Category B or C
children.titleText: Seismic Design Category B or C

children.body: Structures assigned to Seismic Design Category D, E or F shall be designed and detailed in accordance with AISC 341, except as permitted in ASCE 7, Table 15.4-1. Beam-to-column moment connections in special moment frames and intermediate moment frames shall be prequalified in accordance with AISC 341, Section K1, qualified by testing in accordance with AISC 341, Section K2, or shall be prequalified in accordance with AISC 358.
children.displayTitle: 2205.2.1.2 Seismic Design Category D, E or F
children.titleText: Seismic Design Category D, E or F

children.body:
The design, detailing, fabrication and erection of structural steel elements in seismic force-resisting systems other than those covered in Section 2205.2.1, including struts, collectors, chords and foundation elements, shall be in accordance with AISC 341 where either of the following applies:
  1. The structure is assigned to Seismic Design Category D, E or F, except as permitted in ASCE 7, Table 15.4-1.
  2. A response modification coefficient, R, greater than 3 in accordance with ASCE 7, Table 12.2-1, is used for the design of the structure assigned to Seismic Design Category B or C.

diagrams.title: Steel Floor / Roof with Metal Deck: Example 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Composite steel and concrete deck construction has steel decking spanning between steel beams. These steel beams have welded studs that create an interface with the concrete. This causes the steel beam and the steel deck to structurally operate as a single system, similar to a T-beam concrete beam/slab system. The concrete may have embedded rebar for masonry parapets or embeds for things such as bracing or suspended ceiling systems. Coordination with the Structural Engineer of Record is necessary to ensure the proper assembly is selected to provide the proper fire ratings. In addition, Sprayed Fire-Resistant Materials may be required on the underside of the deck to provide the requisite resistance rating.

diagrams.title: Steel Floor / Roof with Metal Deck: Example
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Composite steel and concrete deck construction has steel decking spanning between steel beams. These steel beams have welded studs that create an interface with the concrete. This causes the steel beam and the steel deck to structurally operate as a single system, similar to a T-beam concrete beam/slab system. The concrete may have embedded rebar for masonry parapets or embeds for things such as bracing or suspended ceiling systems. Coordination with the Structural Engineer of Record is necessary to ensure the proper assembly is selected to provide the proper fire ratings. In addition, Sprayed Fire-Resistant Materials may be required on the underside of the deck to provide the requisite resistance rating.

children.displayTitle: Section 2206 Composite Structural Steel and Concrete Structures
children.titleText: Composite Structural Steel and Concrete Structures

children.body: Systems of structural steel elements acting compositely with reinforced concrete shall be designed in accordance with AISC 360 and ACI 318, excluding ACI 318 Chapter 14.
Where required, the seismic design, fabrication and erection of composite steel and concrete systems shall be in accordance with Section 2206.2.1.

Where a response modification coefficient, R, in accordance with ASCE 7, Table 12.2-1, is used for the design of systems of structural steel acting compositely with reinforced concrete, the structures shall be designed and detailed in accordance with the requirements of AISC 341.
children.displayTitle: 2206.2.1 Seismic Requirements for Composite Structural Steel and Concrete Construction
children.titleText: Seismic Requirements for Composite Structural Steel and Concrete Construction

children.body: The design, manufacture and use of open-web steel joists and joist girders shall be in accordance with either SJI 100 or SJI 200, as applicable.
Where required, the seismic design of buildings shall be in accordance with the additional provisions of Section 2205.2 or 2211.1.1.

The registered design professional shall indicate on the construction documents the steel joist and steel joist girder designations from the specifications listed in Section 2207.1; and shall indicate the requirements for joist and joist girder design, layout, end supports, anchorage, bridging design that differs from the SJI specifications listed in Section 2207.1, bridging termination connections and bearing connection design to resist uplift and lateral loads. These documents shall indicate special requirements as follows:
  1. Special loads including:
    1. Concentrated loads.
    2. Nonuniform loads.
    3. Net uplift loads.
    4. Axial loads.
    5. End moments.
    6. Connection forces.
  2. Special considerations including:
    1. Profiles for joist and joist girder configurations that differ from those defined by the SJI specifications listed in Section 2207.1.
    2. Oversized or other nonstandard web openings.
    3. Extended ends.
  3. Live and total load deflection criteria for joists and joist girder configurations that differ from those defined by the SJI specifications listed in Section 2207.1.

The steel joist and joist girder manufacturer shall design the steel joists and steel joist girders in accordance with the SJI specifications listed in Section 2207.1 to support the load requirements of Section 2207.2. The registered design professional shall be permitted to require submission of the steel joist and joist girder calculations as prepared by a registered design professional responsible for the product design. Where requested by the registered design professional, the steel joist manufacturer shall submit design calculations with a cover letter bearing the seal and signature of the joist manufacturer's registered design professional. In addition to the design calculations submitted under seal and signature, the following shall be included:
  1. Bridging design that differs from the SJI specifications listed in Section 2207.1, such as cantilevered conditions and net uplift.
  2. Connection design for:
    1. Connections that differ from the SJI specifications listed in Section 2207.1, such as flush-framed or framed connections.
    2. Field splices.
    3. Joist headers.

Steel joist placement plans shall be provided to show the steel joist products as specified on the approved construction documents and are to be utilized for field installation in accordance with specific project requirements as stated in Section 2207.2. Steel joist placement plans shall include, at a minimum, the following:
  1. Listing of applicable loads as stated in Section 2207.2 and used in the design of the steel joists and joist girders as specified in the approved construction documents.
  2. Profiles for joist and joist girder configurations that differ from those defined by the SJI specifications listed in Section 2207.1.
  3. Connection requirements for:
    1. Joist supports.
    2. Joist girder supports.
    3. Field splices.
    4. Bridging attachments.
  4. Live and total load deflection criteria for joists and joist girder configurations that differ from those defined by the SJI specifications listed in Section 2207.1.
  5. Size, location and connections for bridging.
  6. Joist headers.
Steel joist placement plans do not require the seal and signature of the joist manufacturer's registered design professional.

At completion of manufacture, the steel joist manufacturer shall submit a certificate of compliance to the owner or the owner's authorized agent for submittal to the building official as specified in Section 1704.5 stating that work was performed in accordance with approved construction documents and with SJI specifications listed in Section 2207.1.
The design, fabrication and erection including related connections, and protective coatings of steel cables for buildings shall be in accordance with ASCE 19.

The design, testing and utilization of steel storage racks made of cold-formed or hot-rolled steel structural members shall be in accordance with RMI ANSI/MH 16.1. Where required by ASCE 7, the seismic design of steel storage racks shall be in accordance with Section 15.5.3 of ASCE 7.

The design, testing and utilization of steel cantilevered storage racks made of cold-formed or hot-rolled steel structural members shall be in accordance with RMI ANSI/MH 16.3. Where required by ASCE 7, the seismic design of steel cantilevered storage racks shall be in accordance with Section 15.5.3 of ASCE 7.

For rack storage structures that are 8 feet (2438 mm) in height or greater to the top load level and assigned to Seismic Design Category D, E, or F at completion of the storage rack installation, a certificate of compliance shall be submitted to the owner or the owner's authorized agent stating that the work was performed in accordance with approved construction documents.

diagrams.title: Example: Metal Deck Openings, Details 1 & 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An example is shown of one method of reinforcing openings in metal decks. Appropriate details should be developed by the project's structural engineer of record on a case by case basis. Openings in the diaphragm affect the shear flow to the lateral force resisting system, and larger openings, or openings placed near the LFRS, requires even more attention.

diagrams.title: Example: Metal Deck Openings, Details 3 & 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An example is shown of one method of reinforcing openings in metal decks. Appropriate details should be developed by the project's structural engineer of record on a case by case basis. Openings in the diaphragm affect the shear flow to the lateral force resisting system, and larger openings, or openings placed near the LFRS, requires even more attention.

children.body: The design of cold-formed carbon and low-alloy steel structural members shall be in accordance with AISI S100. The design of cold-formed stainless-steel structural members shall be in accordance with ASCE 8. Cold-formed steel light-frame construction shall comply with Section 2211. Where required, the seismic design of cold-formed steel structures shall be in accordance with the additional provisions of Section 2210.2.

diagrams.title: Exterior Envelope: Roof - Insulation Entirely Above Roof Deck
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The energy code defines the required building envelope thermal performance requirements. When using the R-Value-Based method for thermal performance the opaque assemblies must contain insulation that complies with the requirements of table C402.1.3. The opaque assemblies are essentially the building's roofs, walls, floors that are part of the buildings thermal envelop. The table provides the various minimum R-values for different opaque assemblies based on the building's use (Residential or Other) and climate zone. It is important to note that the table calls out different values for the various types of insulation required in each particular assembly type and assigns a separate R-value for each type of insulation. In some assemblies more than one type of insulation may be required and each type must meet the requirements of the table. For example if the design is calling for both Continuous Insulation and Cavity Insulation at a wall the R-value of each needs comply w/ the table. Where Continuous insulation is required for a wall, the continuous insulation may be installed on the interior or exterior side the wall.

diagrams.title: Exterior Envelope: Roof - Metal Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The energy code defines the required building envelope thermal performance requirements. When using the R-Value-Based method for thermal performance the opaque assemblies must contain insulation that complies with the requirements of table C402.1.3. The opaque assemblies are essentially the building's roofs, walls, floors that are part of the buildings thermal envelop. The table provides the various minimum R-values for different opaque assemblies based on the building's use (Residential or Other) and climate zone. It is important to note that the table calls out different values for the various types of insulation required in each particular assembly type and assigns a separate R-value for each type of insulation. In some assemblies more than one type of insulation may be required and each type must meet the requirements of the table. For example if the design is calling for both Continuous Insulation and Cavity Insulation at a wall the R-value of each needs comply w/ the table. Where Continuous insulation is required for a wall, the continuous insulation may be installed on the interior or exterior side the wall.

diagrams.title: Exterior Envelope: Walls - Metal
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The energy code defines the required building envelope thermal performance requirements. When using the R-Value-Based method for thermal performance the opaque assemblies must contain insulation that complies with the requirements of table C402.1.3. The opaque assemblies are essentially the building's roofs, walls, floors that are part of the buildings thermal envelop. The table provides the various minimum R-values for different opaque assemblies based on the building's use (Residential or Other) and climate zone. It is important to note that the table calls out different values for the various types of insulation required in each particular assembly type and assigns a separate R-value for each type of insulation. In some assemblies more than one type of insulation may be required and each type must meet the requirements of the table. For example if the design is calling for both Continuous Insulation and Cavity Insulation at a wall the R-value of each needs comply w/ the table. Where Continuous insulation is required for a wall, the continuous insulation may be installed on the interior or exterior side the wall.

children.body: The design and construction of cold-formed steel decks shall be in accordance with this section.

diagrams.title: Example: Metal Deck Openings, Details 1 & 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An example is shown of one method of reinforcing openings in metal decks. Appropriate details should be developed by the project's structural engineer of record on a case by case basis. Openings in the diaphragm affect the shear flow to the lateral force resisting system, and larger openings, or openings placed near the LFRS, requires even more attention.

diagrams.title: Example: Metal Deck Openings, Details 3 & 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An example is shown of one method of reinforcing openings in metal decks. Appropriate details should be developed by the project's structural engineer of record on a case by case basis. Openings in the diaphragm affect the shear flow to the lateral force resisting system, and larger openings, or openings placed near the LFRS, requires even more attention.

children.body: Noncomposite steel floor decks shall be permitted to be designed and constructed in accordance with ANSI/SDI-NC1.0.
Steel roof decks shall be permitted to be designed and constructed in accordance with ANSI/SDI-RD1.0.
Composite slabs of concrete and steel deck shall be permitted to be designed and constructed in accordance with SDI-C.

Where a response modification coefficient, R, in accordance with ASCE 7, Table 12.2-1, is used for the design of cold-formed steel structures, the structures shall be designed and detailed in accordance with the requirements of AISI S100, ASCE 8, or, for cold-formed steel special-bolted moment frames, AISI S400.
children.displayTitle: 2210.2 Seismic Requirements for Cold-Formed Steel Structures
children.titleText: Seismic Requirements for Cold-Formed Steel Structures

children.body:
For cold-formed steel light-frame construction, the design and installation of the following structural framing systems, including their members and connections, shall be in accordance with AISI S240, and Sections 2211.1.1 through 2211.1.3, as applicable:
  1. Floor and roof systems.
  2. Structural walls.
  3. Shear walls, strap-braced walls and diaphragms that resist in-plane lateral loads.
  4. Trusses.

diagrams.title: Light Gauge Steel Joist Web Stiffeners
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Light gauge steel joists web stiffeners, sometimes called web reinforcement, are elements that are used when the web of a steel joist is subjected to concentrated loads, bearing loads, or reactions that exceed the shearing resistance of the web itself. They provide support and enhance the stability of the steel joist, reducing the potential for local buckling or web crippling.

children.body: The design of cold-formed steel light-frame construction to resist seismic forces shall be in accordance with the provisions of Section 2211.1.1.1 or 2211.1.1.2, as applicable.
children.displayTitle: 2211.1.1 Seismic Requirements for Cold-Formed Steel Structural Systems
children.titleText: Seismic Requirements for Cold-Formed Steel Structural Systems

children.body:
Where a response modification coefficient, R, in accordance with ASCE 7, Table 12.2-1 is used for the design of cold-formed steel light-frame construction assigned to Seismic Design Category B or C, the seismic force-resisting system shall be designed and detailed in accordance with the requirements of AISI S400.
Exception: The response modification coefficient, R, designated for "Steel systems not specifically detailed for seismic resistance, excluding cantilever column systems" in ASCE 7, Table 12.2-1, shall be permitted for systems designed and detailed in accordance with AISI S240 and need not be designed and detailed in accordance with AISI S400
children.displayTitle: 2211.1.1.1 Seismic Design Categories B and C
children.titleText: Seismic Design Categories B and C

children.body: In cold-formed steel light-frame construction assigned to Seismic Design Category D, E or F, the seismic force-resisting system shall be designed and detailed in accordance with AISI S400.
children.displayTitle: 2211.1.1.2 Seismic Design Categories D Through F
children.titleText: Seismic Design Categories D Through F

children.body: Detached one- and two-family dwellings and townhouses, less than or equal to three stories above grade plane, shall be permitted to be constructed in accordance with AISI S230 subject to the limitations therein.
Cold-formed steel trusses shall comply with the additional provisions of Sections 2211.1.3.1 through 2211.1.3.3.

The truss design drawings shall conform to the requirements of Section I1 of AISI S202 and shall be provided with the shipment of trusses delivered to the job site. The truss design drawings shall include the details of permanent individual truss member restraint/bracing in accordance with Section I1.6 of AISI S202 where these methods are utilized to provide restraint/bracing.

The owner or the owner's authorized agent shall contract with a registered design professional for the design of the temporary installation restraint/bracing and the permanent individual truss member restraint/bracing for trusses with clear spans 60 feet (18 288 mm) or greater. Special inspection of trusses over 60 feet (18 288 mm) in length shall be in accordance with Section 1705.2.

Trusses not part of a manufacturing process that provides requirements for quality control done under the supervision of a third-party quality control agency in accordance with AISI S240 Chapter D shall be fabricated in compliance with Sections 1704.2.5 and 1705.2, as applicable.
For cold-formed steel light-frame construction, the design and installation of nonstructural members and connections shall be in accordance with AISI S220.

diagrams.title: Steel Stud Lateral Bracing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Metal studs, especially when they are tall and thin, have a propensity to buckle when subjected to axial loads. Bracing helps in distributing these loads and prevents the individual studs from buckling out of plane.

diagrams.title: Light Gauge Steel Framing Nomenclature
diagrams.descriptionHtml: For light gauge metal framing, manufacturers are required to stamp the stud size and gauge on each product. Products have a four-part identification code that helps identify the web depth, flange width, style and mil thickness for each product.

diagrams.title: Steel Framing Drop Ceiling
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Cold formed steel framing at drop ceiling conditions should also include lateral bracing for the tops of the ceiling joists of longer spans. This strengthens the joists and also helps prevent buckling or rotation of the joist. Lateral strap bracing should be anchored to the adjacent stud framing.

diagrams.title: Side Clip Attachment: Bypass Wall Stud (Steel)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Proprietary or custom designed angles (clips) can be used to attach a metal stud bypassing the floor assembly. Bypass clips are used to attach exterior curtain wall studs to the building structure and provide either a rigid connection or deflecting connection for vertical building movement independent of the cold-formed steel framing.

Where curtain walls are extended on the outside of a spandrel member, a void can be created that could allow for the passage of smoke or flames. Special consideration of these conditions is required.

diagrams.title: Steel Stud Lateral Bracing and Stiffeners
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Metal studs, especially when they are tall and thin, have a propensity to buckle when subjected to axial loads. Bracing helps in distributing these loads and prevents the individual studs from buckling out of plane.

diagrams.title: Holes in Non-Structural Steel Studs
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Non-Structural cold formed steel framing studs may not be cut or notched in the lip or flange areas of the stud. Holes are only permitted along the centerline of the web. Holes in the web may be up to 1-1/2" wide by 4" tall. Holes may not be less than 10" from either end of the stud. Holes must be at least 24" apart measured center to center from one another.

diagrams.title: Example: Partial Hght. Wall Bracing - Alt. Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Partial height walls require bracing to resist out of plane loads equal to 5 pounds per square foot. This is an example one potential method to provide such bracing. Source: OSHPD.CA.GOV. OPD No. ST6.03

diagrams.title: Example: Partial Height Wall Top Bracing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Partial height walls require bracing to resist out of plane loads equal to 5 pounds per square foot. This is an example one potential method to provide such bracing. Source: OSHPD.CA.GOV. OPD No. ST6.02

diagrams.title: Partition Live Loads
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In building types where partitions are subject to change over time the code requires that the floor structure is able to accommodate future partition changes. To ensure the floor can handle partition loads that change over time, the floor with a specified live load <80 psf are required to to accommodate an additional 15 psf of uniformly distributed live load. This applies to any building in which partitions are subject to frequent changes such as malls, commercial office or retail buildings. In buildings such as hospitals where it may be unclear or the designer is unsure if walls are subject to change, the designer should consult with the Authority Having Jurisdiction.

diagrams.title: Example: Interior Metal Stud Partition / Concrete Slab Firestopping
Example: Metal Stud Wall Top / Steel Deck Firestopping
